title: Acts Chapter 28 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Acts chapter 28 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Acts Chapter 28 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Acts Chapter 28.

questions.question: What was the name of the island where Paul and others were shipwrecked?
questions.correctAnswer: Melita
questions.explanation: Acts 28:1 states that the island was called Melita.

questions.question: How did the barbarous people treat Paul and the others when they arrived on the island?
options: They showed kindness and kindled a fire
questions.correctAnswer: They showed kindness and kindled a fire
questions.explanation: Acts 28:2 says the barbarous people showed kindness, kindled a fire, and received them because of the rain and cold.

questions.question: What happened to Paul when he gathered sticks and laid them on the fire?
questions.correctAnswer: A viper bit his hand
questions.explanation: Acts 28:3 describes a viper coming out of the fire and fastening on Paul's hand.

questions.question: What did the islanders initially think about Paul after the viper bit him?
questions.correctAnswer: He was a murderer
questions.explanation: Acts 28:4 explains that the barbarians thought Paul was a murderer who escaped the sea but vengeance would not let him live.

questions.question: Did Paul suffer harm from the viper bite?
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 28:5 states that Paul shook off the viper into the fire and felt no harm.

questions.question: What conclusion did the islanders come to after seeing Paul was unharmed by the viper bite?
questions.correctAnswer: He was a god
questions.explanation: Acts 28:6 shows that the islanders changed their minds and said Paul was a god after seeing no harm came to him.

questions.question: Who was the chief man of the island who hosted Paul and the others?
questions.correctAnswer: Publius
questions.explanation: Acts 28:7 identifies Publius as the chief man of the island who courteously received them.

questions.question: What illness did the father of Publius suffer from?
questions.correctAnswer: Fever and bloody flux
questions.explanation: Acts 28:8 states the father of Publius was sick with a fever and bloody flux.

questions.question: How long did Paul and the others stay on the island before departing?
questions.correctAnswer: Three months
questions.explanation: Acts 28:11 says they stayed three months before departing in a ship from Alexandria.

questions.question: Where did Paul and the others land after departing the island?
questions.correctAnswer: Syracuse
questions.explanation: Acts 28:12 states they landed at Syracuse and stayed three days.

questions.question: True or False: Paul was allowed to live by himself with a soldier in Rome.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Acts 28:16 mentions Paul was permitted to dwell by himself with a soldier who kept him.

questions.question: What reason did Paul give for being bound with a chain?
questions.correctAnswer: For the hope of Israel
questions.explanation: Acts 28:20 states Paul was bound with a chain for the hope of Israel.

questions.question: What did Paul do when the chief of the Jews came to him in Rome?
options: He expounded and testified the kingdom of God
questions.correctAnswer: He expounded and testified the kingdom of God
questions.explanation: Acts 28:23 describes Paul explaining and testifying the kingdom of God from morning till evening.

questions.question: True or False: All the Jews believed the things Paul spoke about Jesus.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 28:24 states some believed and some did not believe the things Paul spoke.

questions.question: Complete the verse: 'And Paul dwelt two whole years in his own ______ house, and received all that came in unto him.'
questions.correctAnswer: hired
questions.explanation: Acts 28:30 says Paul dwelt two whole years in his own hired house.

medium.title: Acts Chapter 28 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Acts Chapter 28 to real-life situations.

questions.question: How does the response of the islanders to Paul's snakebite teach us about faith and trust in God during unexpected trials?
options: They recognized Paul as a god after seeing no harm come to him
They immediately helped Paul pray for healing
They ignored the event and continued on their way
They blamed Paul and rejected him
questions.correctAnswer: They recognized Paul as a god after seeing no harm come to him
questions.explanation: Acts 28:3-6 shows that the islanders initially thought Paul was a murderer bitten by a viper. After he shook off the snake and suffered no harm, they changed their minds and said he was a god. This teaches us that faith and trust in God's protection can transform how others perceive us during trials.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with discouragement after enduring hardship. Based on Acts 28, what biblical truth about perseverance and God’s care would you share?
options: God provides kindness and healing even through difficult circumstances
We must always avoid hardships at all costs
Only those who are perfect are protected by God
Suffering is a sign that God has abandoned us
questions.correctAnswer: God provides kindness and healing even through difficult circumstances
questions.explanation: Acts 28:2, 8-9 shows that despite the harsh situation of shipwreck and snakebite, God’s kindness was shown through the islanders and Paul’s healing ministry. This encourages believers to persevere, trusting in God’s care and provision.

questions.question: What does Paul’s healing of Publius’ father demonstrate about serving others in times of need?
options: Praying and using God’s power to help those who are sick
Ignoring physical needs and focusing only on spiritual matters
Relying solely on medicine without prayer
Only helping those who can repay us
questions.correctAnswer: Praying and using God’s power to help those who are sick
questions.explanation: Acts 28:8-9 shows Paul praying and laying hands to heal Publius’ sick father, and subsequently others. This demonstrates the Christian call to serve others through prayer and compassion in their physical needs.

questions.question: How does the hospitality shown by the islanders toward Paul and his companions model generosity and fellowship?
options: They received them kindly, hosted them for three days, and provided necessities upon departure
They refused to help and sent them away
They charged them high prices for lodging
They forced them to work for their stay
questions.correctAnswer: They received them kindly, hosted them for three days, and provided necessities upon departure
questions.explanation: Acts 28:2, 7, 10 illustrate the islanders’ kindness and generosity in hospitality, welcoming Paul and companions and honoring them with gifts. This models the biblical virtue of welcoming and serving others.

questions.question: A believer feels isolated in their faith journey. What encouragement about fellowship and support can be drawn from Paul’s journey toward Rome?
options: Brethren met Paul along the way and encouraged him, strengthening his courage
Paul traveled alone without any support
Paul discouraged fellowship to focus on solitude
questions.correctAnswer: Brethren met Paul along the way and encouraged him, strengthening his courage
questions.explanation: Acts 28:14-15 describes how brethren met Paul on his journey and encouraged him, which gave Paul courage and thanksgiving to God. This teaches the importance of fellowship and mutual support in the Christian life.

questions.question: What lesson about integrity and honesty is seen in Paul’s defense before the Jewish leaders in Rome?
options: Paul declared he had committed no offense against his people or customs
Paul admitted to wrongdoing to gain favor
Paul refused to speak with the leaders
Paul blamed others for his imprisonment
questions.correctAnswer: Paul declared he had committed no offense against his people or customs
questions.explanation: Acts 28:17-18 shows Paul openly stating his innocence and integrity before the Jewish leaders, emphasizing honesty even under trial. This exemplifies maintaining integrity in difficult situations.

questions.question: According to Acts 28, how should Christians respond when their message is met with skepticism or rejection?
options: Continue to testify about the kingdom of God with patience and confidence
Stop sharing the message to avoid conflict
Only share with those who already believe
Argue aggressively to prove the message
questions.correctAnswer: Continue to testify about the kingdom of God with patience and confidence
questions.explanation: Acts 28:23-24, 30-31 show Paul expounding the kingdom of God and teaching about Jesus with confidence, despite some believing and some not. This encourages perseverance in evangelism.

questions.question: True or False: Paul was not allowed to live by himself in Rome but was kept in a prison cell with many others.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 28:16 states that Paul was allowed to dwell by himself with a soldier who kept him, indicating a degree of freedom and personal space, unlike being confined with many prisoners.

questions.question: True or False: The Jewish leaders in Rome had received letters condemning Paul before he arrived.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 28:21 records that the Jewish leaders said they neither received letters concerning Paul nor had brethren reported any harm from him, showing Paul’s good reputation among them.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Paul said, "For the hope of _____ I am bound with this chain."
questions.correctAnswer: Israel
questions.explanation: Acts 28:20 records Paul stating he is bound with a chain for the hope of Israel, highlighting his commitment to his people despite imprisonment.

questions.question: How does Acts 28 teach us about spiritual humility and contentment during trials?
options: Paul lived in a hired house for two years and received all who came to him
Paul isolated himself and refused visitors
Paul complained constantly about his imprisonment
questions.correctAnswer: Paul lived in a hired house for two years and received all who came to him
questions.explanation: Acts 28:30 shows Paul’s contentment and hospitality even while under house arrest, modeling humility and openness in difficult circumstances.

questions.question: What does Paul’s use of Scripture from morning till evening to explain Jesus reveal about the importance of personal devotion and study?
options: Consistent study and teaching of Scripture are essential for effective evangelism
Only spontaneous sharing without preparation is necessary
Scripture is irrelevant to explaining Jesus
Teaching should be brief and limited
questions.correctAnswer: Consistent study and teaching of Scripture are essential for effective evangelism
questions.explanation: Acts 28:23 describes Paul expounding and testifying from the law and prophets from morning until evening, showing dedication to Scripture study as the foundation of evangelism.

questions.question: Based on Acts 28, what biblical virtue is demonstrated by the islanders’ willingness to care for Paul and others with diseases?
options: Compassion and service to those in need
questions.correctAnswer: Compassion and service to those in need
questions.explanation: Acts 28:9-10 reveals that after Paul healed Publius’ father, others with diseases came and were healed too, showing the islanders’ compassion and willingness to serve.

questions.question: How does Paul’s appeal unto Caesar, despite having no charges, teach about humility and trust in God's plan?
options: Paul accepted his circumstances and trusted God’s sovereign plan
Paul resisted and tried to escape at all costs
Paul blamed others for his troubles
questions.correctAnswer: Paul accepted his circumstances and trusted God’s sovereign plan
questions.explanation: Acts 28:19-20 shows Paul appealing to Caesar not out of guilt but obedience, trusting God’s will even in chains, teaching humility and perseverance.

questions.question: What practical Christian lesson on evangelism can be drawn from the mixed response of the Jewish leaders to Paul’s message?
options: Expect some to believe and some to reject; continue faithfully
Only preach where all will accept the message
Stop sharing if anyone rejects the message
Use force to make others believe
questions.correctAnswer: Expect some to believe and some to reject; continue faithfully
questions.explanation: Acts 28:24-25 shows some believed and some did not, yet Paul continued to preach faithfully, teaching perseverance in sharing the gospel despite varied responses.

hard.title: Acts Chapter 28 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Acts Chapter 28.

questions.question: What was the name of the island where Paul and others were shipwrecked?
questions.correctAnswer: Melita
questions.explanation: Acts 28:1 explicitly states that the island was called Melita, marking the setting for the events that follow.

questions.question: How did the islanders, described as 'barbarous people,' treat Paul and the shipwrecked group?
options: They showed kindness by kindling a fire and receiving them
questions.correctAnswer: They showed kindness by kindling a fire and receiving them
questions.explanation: Acts 28:2 emphasizes the kindness of the 'barbarous people' who helped the shipwrecked by providing fire and shelter against the cold and rain.

questions.question: What type of creature bit Paul when he was gathering sticks, and what was the significance of this event?
options: A viper; Paul was unharmed, leading islanders to think he was a god
A scorpion; it caused Paul great pain
A lion; it was immediately driven away
questions.correctAnswer: A viper; Paul was unharmed, leading islanders to think he was a god
questions.explanation: Acts 28:3-6 narrate the event where a viper bites Paul but he suffers no harm, causing the islanders to reverse their judgment and call him a god, showing typology of divine protection.

questions.question: Who was Publius, and what role did he play during Paul's stay on the island?
options: The chief man of the island who hosted Paul and was healed by him
A Roman centurion who guarded Paul
The owner of the ship that rescued Paul
A Jewish leader who opposed Paul
questions.correctAnswer: The chief man of the island who hosted Paul and was healed by him
questions.explanation: Acts 28:7-8 identifies Publius as the chief man of the island who courteously received Paul and his companions, and whose sick father Paul healed, illustrating hospitality and miraculous healing.

questions.question: What does Paul's healing of Publius' father and others on the island signify in a broader biblical context?
options: It foreshadows Jesus’ healing ministry and the inclusion of Gentiles in God’s salvation plan
It was a common practice among apostles to heal only Jews
It demonstrates Paul's political power on the island
It was a symbolic act of cleansing the island from paganism
questions.correctAnswer: It foreshadows Jesus’ healing ministry and the inclusion of Gentiles in God’s salvation plan
questions.explanation: Acts 28:8-9 shows Paul healing Gentiles, paralleling Jesus’ ministry and emphasizing the expansion of salvation beyond Israel, a key theme in Luke-Acts.

questions.question: Which ship did Paul and his companions take after three months, and what is significant about its sign?
options: A ship of Alexandria with the sign Castor and Pollux
A ship from Rome with the sign of the eagle
A ship from Corinth with the sign of Apollo
A ship from Athens with the sign of Zeus
questions.correctAnswer: A ship of Alexandria with the sign Castor and Pollux
questions.explanation: Acts 28:11 mentions the ship of Alexandria with the sign Castor and Pollux, referencing the twin gods of sailors in Greco-Roman culture, indicating historical and cultural context.

questions.question: After arriving in Rome, how was Paul treated regarding his imprisonment and living arrangements?
options: He was allowed to live by himself with a soldier to guard him
He was thrown into a dark dungeon
He was placed under house arrest with no guards
questions.correctAnswer: He was allowed to live by himself with a soldier to guard him
questions.explanation: Acts 28:16 reveals that Paul was permitted to dwell by himself with a soldier, showing a degree of freedom unusual for prisoners, reflecting Roman legal practices and possibly Paul's status.

questions.question: Why did Paul call together the chief of the Jews in Rome after three days of his arrival?
options: To explain that he was bound for the hope of Israel and was wrongly imprisoned
To announce his release from prison
To warn them about the Gentiles
To seek financial support for his ministry
questions.correctAnswer: To explain that he was bound for the hope of Israel and was wrongly imprisoned
questions.explanation: Acts 28:17-20 shows Paul addressing the Jewish leaders to clarify his innocence and to testify about his faith and hope in Israel, emphasizing his mission and legal situation.

questions.question: What was the reaction of the Jewish leaders in Rome when Paul spoke to them about his mission and the 'hope of Israel'?
options: They neither received letters about him nor heard harm from others and desired to hear more
They immediately rejected him and expelled him
They welcomed him as a prophet
They arrested him on the spot
questions.correctAnswer: They neither received letters about him nor heard harm from others and desired to hear more
questions.explanation: Acts 28:21-22 records that the Jewish leaders had no prior negative reports about Paul and expressed a desire to understand his teachings, illustrating openness amid skepticism.

questions.question: How long did Paul preach and teach in his lodging in Rome, and what was the nature of his teaching?
options: Two whole years, preaching the kingdom of God and teaching about Jesus Christ with confidence
Six months, focusing on Jewish law exclusively
One year, teaching only the Gentiles
questions.correctAnswer: Two whole years, preaching the kingdom of God and teaching about Jesus Christ with confidence
questions.explanation: Acts 28:30-31 describes Paul’s extended ministry in Rome, highlighting his bold and uninterrupted teaching about Jesus and the kingdom of God, central to the book’s theme.

questions.question: What Old Testament prophet does Paul quote when some Jews reject his message, and what is the main theme of the quotation?
options: Isaiah; the people's hearts are hardened and they will not understand or be converted
Jeremiah; the promise of a new covenant
Ezekiel; the vision of dry bones
Daniel; the prophecy of the seventy weeks
questions.correctAnswer: Isaiah; the people's hearts are hardened and they will not understand or be converted
questions.explanation: Acts 28:25-27 cites Isaiah to explain the rejection of the gospel by some Jews, illustrating the theme of spiritual blindness and fulfillment of prophecy.

questions.question: What is the significance of the statement, 'the salvation of God is sent unto the Gentiles,' in the context of Acts 28?
options: It marks the expansion of God's redemptive plan beyond Israel to the Gentiles
It means the Jews have been completely rejected by God
It refers only to the islanders of Melita
It indicates a future event not yet fulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: It marks the expansion of God's redemptive plan beyond Israel to the Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 28:28 underscores a major theological theme in Luke-Acts: the gospel’s reach to the Gentiles, fulfilling God’s promise to Abraham and connecting with earlier scriptures like Isaiah.

questions.question: Which phrase best describes the literary structure around the snake bite incident in Acts 28:3-6?
options: Chiasm, with the snake bite and Paul's unharmed state as pivotal elements
Parallelism between Paul's trial and shipwreck
Typology of Moses' staff turning into a serpent
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm, with the snake bite and Paul's unharmed state as pivotal elements
questions.explanation: The narrative in Acts 28:3-6 shows a chiasmic structure focusing on the snake bite and the miraculous protection of Paul, highlighting divine intervention and echoing biblical motifs of deliverance.

questions.question: True or False: The Jewish leaders in Rome unanimously accepted Paul's message after he explained his mission.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Acts 28:24-29 reveal that while some believed Paul's message, others did not, leading to disagreement among the Jews, showing the mixed reception of the gospel.

questions.question: What cultural or historical significance does the sign 'Castor and Pollux' on the ship have in the context of Acts 28:11?
options: It refers to the twin gods of sailors in Greco-Roman mythology, symbolizing protection at sea
It was a symbol of Jewish heritage
It indicated the ship was owned by the Roman government
It was a Christian symbol used by early believers
questions.correctAnswer: It refers to the twin gods of sailors in Greco-Roman mythology, symbolizing protection at sea
questions.explanation: Acts 28:11’s mention of Castor and Pollux points to the cultural milieu of the ancient Mediterranean, reflecting the author's awareness of pagan symbolism and the historical context of Paul's travels.

theological.title: Acts Chapter 28 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Acts Chapter 28 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What was the name of the island where Paul and the others were shipwrecked?
questions.correctAnswer: Melita
questions.explanation: Acts 28:1 states that after escaping the shipwreck, they knew the island was called Melita. This aligns with other biblical references where God directs His people to specific places (e.g., Jonah 1:3, Acts 27:39-44).

questions.question: How did the 'barbarous people' treat Paul and the others upon their arrival on the island?
questions.correctAnswer: With kindness and hospitality
questions.explanation: Acts 28:2 shows the islanders showed kindness by kindling a fire and receiving them because of the rain and cold. This reflects God's providential care for His servants (Psalm 23:6, Romans 8:28).

questions.question: What happened when Paul gathered sticks and laid them on the fire?
options: A viper fastened on his hand
He was healed of a wound
questions.correctAnswer: A viper fastened on his hand
questions.explanation: Acts 28:3 records that a viper came out of the heat and fastened on Paul's hand. This event demonstrates the sovereignty of God over nature and trials (Mark 16:18, Luke 10:19).

questions.question: What did the islanders conclude about Paul when they saw he was not harmed by the viper bite?
options: They said he was a god
They said he was a sorcerer
questions.correctAnswer: They said he was a god
questions.explanation: Acts 28:6 explains that when Paul was unharmed, the islanders changed their minds and said he was a god. This reflects the biblical theme of divine protection and the recognition of God's power (Exodus 14:31, Daniel 3:25).

questions.question: Who was the chief man of the island who hosted Paul and his companions?
questions.correctAnswer: Publius
questions.explanation: Acts 28:7 identifies Publius as the chief man of the island who courteously received Paul and his companions. This shows God's providence in providing hospitality (Genesis 18:1-8, Hebrews 13:2).

questions.question: What miraculous event occurred when Paul prayed for Publius' sick father?
options: He was healed of fever and bloody flux
He was raised from the dead
He was given a prophetic vision
questions.correctAnswer: He was healed of fever and bloody flux
questions.explanation: Acts 28:8 states that Paul prayed and laid hands on Publius' father, healing him. This affirms Christ's healing ministry continued through the apostles (Matthew 10:8, James 5:14-15).

questions.question: How long did Paul stay on the island before departing to Rome?
questions.correctAnswer: Three months
questions.explanation: Acts 28:11 records that after three months on the island, they departed for Rome. This reflects the providential timing of God's plans (Genesis 41:1, Acts 21:11).

questions.question: What was the name of the ship that took Paul from Melita to Rome?
questions.correctAnswer: Ship of Alexandria
questions.explanation: Acts 28:11 mentions the ship of Alexandria, whose sign was Castor and Pollux, which took them from Melita. This shows the historical and geographic reality of Paul's journey (Acts 27:6).

questions.question: Upon arrival in Rome, what was Paul's living situation?
options: He was allowed to dwell by himself with a soldier
He was imprisoned in a dungeon
He was housed with Jewish leaders
questions.correctAnswer: He was allowed to dwell by himself with a soldier
questions.explanation: Acts 28:16 states that Paul was allowed to live by himself with a soldier keeping him, indicating a form of house arrest. This shows God's sovereignty in Paul's ministry despite imprisonment (Philippians 1:13-14).

questions.question: Why did Paul appeal to Caesar according to his own testimony?
options: Because the Jews opposed his release
Because he wanted to avoid trial
Because he was guilty of a crime
Because he sought to flee Rome
questions.correctAnswer: Because the Jews opposed his release
questions.explanation: Acts 28:19 explains Paul appealed to Caesar because the Jews spoke against his release, not because he had any accusation against his nation. This highlights God's providential use of political systems for His purposes (Romans 13:1-7).

questions.question: What reason did Paul give for calling the chief of the Jews together in Rome?
options: To speak of the hope of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: To speak of the hope of Israel
questions.explanation: Acts 28:20 states Paul called the Jews to speak with them because he was bound for the hope of Israel, emphasizing the eschatological hope rooted in Messiah (Romans 11:26, Jeremiah 23:5-6).

questions.question: How did the Jewish leaders respond to Paul's message about the sect known as Christianity?
options: They desired to hear more about it
questions.correctAnswer: They desired to hear more about it
questions.explanation: Acts 28:22 records that the Jews said they desired to hear Paul's thoughts because the sect was spoken against everywhere. This interaction shows the tension between tradition and the new covenant (John 1:11, Acts 7:51).

questions.question: What Old Testament prophet did Paul quote to explain the unbelief of the Jews?
questions.correctAnswer: Esaias (Isaiah)
questions.explanation: Acts 28:25-27 cites Isaiah (Esaias) to explain the hardened hearts of the people, reflecting fulfillment of prophecy about Israel's rejection of the Messiah (Isaiah 6:9-10, John 12:39-40).

questions.question: According to Paul, to whom has God sent salvation at this point?
questions.correctAnswer: The Gentiles
questions.explanation: Acts 28:28 declares that salvation is sent to the Gentiles, and they will hear it, revealing the expansion of God's covenant to include all nations (Genesis 12:3, Galatians 3:8).

questions.question: How long did Paul dwell in Rome, preaching the kingdom of God?
questions.correctAnswer: Two whole years
questions.explanation: Acts 28:30 states Paul stayed two whole years in his own rented house, preaching with confidence, demonstrating God's faithfulness in sustaining His servant (2 Timothy 4:17).
